qas.question: What do Czech typographical features not associated with phonetics tend to resemble?

answers.text: those of most Latin European languages

qas.question: In Czech, what is done to proper nouns, honorifics, and the first letters of quotations?
What is typical in Czech as other Latin European languages?
What language does Czech share its handling of ordinal format with?
What word is capitalized in proper noun phrases in Czech?
What does English use instead of a decimal point?
What can be used in Latin when writing noun phrases?
What word is capitalized in phonetics in Latin?
What can always be used in decimal places in Latin?
Latin uses a decimal comma instead of what?

context: Czech typographical features not associated with phonetics generally resemble <a0_0>those of most Latin European languages<a0_0/>, including English. Proper nouns, honorifics, and the first letters of quotations are <a1_0>capitalized<a1_0/>, and <a2_0>punctuation<a2_0/> is typical of other Latin European languages. Writing of ordinal numerals is similar to most European languages. The Czech language uses <b5_0>a decimal comma<b5_0/> instead of <b9_0>a decimal point<b9_0/>. When writing a long number, <b6_0><b8_0>spaces between every three numbers<b8_0/><b6_0/> (e.g. between hundreds and thousands) may be used for better orientation in handwritten texts, but not in decimal places, like in English. The number 1,234,567.8910 may be written as 1234567,8910 or 1 234 567,8910. Ordinal numbers (1st) use a point as in <a3_0>German<a3_0/> (1.). In proper noun phrases (except personal names), <a4_0><b7_0>only the first<a4_0/> word<b7_0/> is capitalized (Pražský hrad, Prague Castle).
